questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a:
questions.solution:
The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a fibrous joint (syndesmosis).

The radius and ulna are united with each other by three joints:

  • Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint
  • Middle radioulnar joint
  • Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:

  • The oblique cord - extends from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity to the radius, distal to the radial tuberosity.
  • Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

Based on the structure, joints are classified into three types:

  • Fibrous joints
    • Sutures
    • Syndesmosis
    • Gomphosis
  • Cartilaginous joints
    • Primary cartilaginous joints or synchondrosis
    • Secondary cartilaginous joints or symphysis
  • Synovial joints
    • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
    • Sellar or saddle joints
    • Condylar or bicondylar joints
    • Ellipsoid joints
    • Hinge joints
    • Pivot or trochoid joints
    • Plane joints

The illustration below depicts types of fibrous joints.

The illustration below depicts the types of synovial joints.

questions.text: The maximum amount of air that can be expelled from the lungs after first filling the lungs to their maximum extent and then expiring to the maximum extent is equal to :
questions.solution:
The maximum amount of air that can be expelled from the lungs after first filling the lungs to their maximum extent and then expiring to the maximum extent is equal to vital capacity of lungs.

It is the sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume and expiratory reserve volume. It is around 4600 mL.

Other options:

Option A: Functional residual capacity is the sum of expiratory reserve volume and residual volume and it is the total amout of air remanining in the lungs after normal expiration. It is about 2300 mL.

Option B: The total lung capacity is the maximum volume to which lungs can be expanded with the greatest effort. It is about 5800 mL and the sum of vital capacity and the residual volume.

Option D: The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level and is about 3500 mL.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy with features of angular stomatitis and a magenta tongue is diagnosed to have a deficiency of a certain water-soluble vitamin. Which of the following vitamins could it be?
questions.solution:
The boy is most likely to have a Vitamin B2 / Riboflavin deficiency.

Riboflavin is important for the metabolism of fat, carbohydrate, and protein, acting as a respiratory coenzyme and an electron donor. Enzymes that contain flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) or flavin mononucleotide (FMN) as prosthetic groups are known as flavoenzymes (e.g., succinic acid dehydrogenase, monoamine oxidase, glutathione reductase). FAD is a cofactor for methyltetrahydrofolate reductase and therefore modulates homocysteine metabolism. The vitamin also plays a role in drug and steroid metabolism, including detoxification reactions.

The clinical manifestations of riboflavin deficiency are nonspecific; patients with a Vitamin B2 / Thiamine deficiency usually present with features of a magenta-coloured tongue, angular stomatitis, seborrhea, ocular symptoms, corneal vascularization. Risk factors include alcoholism and a poor diet with a low intake of milk products. In addition, corneal vascularization, anaemia, and personality changes have been observed with riboflavin deficiency.

Riboflavin deficiency almost always is due to dietary deficiency. Milk and other dairy products, enriched bread, cereals, meat, fish, eggs, broccoli, and legumes are good sources of riboflavin. It is extremely sensitive to light, and milk should be stored in containers that protect against its photodegradation. Laboratory diagnosis of riboflavin deficiency can be made by determination of red blood cell or urinary riboflavin concentrations or by measurement of erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity.

Other options:

Option B: Vitamin B3/ Niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterised by a pigmented rash in skin exposed areas, bright red tongue, diarrhoea, apathy, memory loss and disorientation.

Option C: Vitamin B6/ Pyridoxine deficiency leads to symptoms such as seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion and microcytic anaemia.

Option D: Vitamin E is a fat-soluble vitamin and is not soluble in water. Its deficiency leads to peripheral neuropathy, spinocerebellar ataxia, skeletal muscle atrophy, retinopathy.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with a history of morning headaches, vomiting, and lethargy for the past 6 months.  MRI scan showed a contrast-enhancing nodule in the cerebellum. Biopsy findings of the tumor are shown in the image. The tumors were positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of a child presenting with symptoms of increased intracranial tension with an image that shows Rosenthal fibers are suggestive of pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a brain tumour that occurs more often in children and young adults. These tumours are usually slow-growing and benign. The majority of neoplasms are located in the cerebellum. However, they can also appear around the third ventricle, optic nerves, spinal cord, and occasionally in the cerebral hemispheres.

On brain MRI, it can be identified as a contrast-enhancing nodule. On microscopy, it has very limited brain invasion compared to infiltrative astrocytomas. The tumour is made up of bipolar cells with hair-like projections forming a dense fibrillary meshwork. These cells are positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). The characteristic features of this tumour are the presence of Rosenthal fibres and eosinophilic granular bodies. A Rosenthal fibre is a corkscrew-shaped eosinophilic inclusion while eosinophilic granular bodies are mulberry-shaped inclusions.

In low-grade astrocytoma, surgical resection is the primary treatment modality, and in high-grade lesions, local irradiation is also done after surgical correction.

The below image shows pilocytic astrocytoma with Rosenthal fibers (arrows) and dense fibrillary meshwork.

Other options:

Option A- Ependymomas are the tumors that arise from the ependyma-lined ventricular system. The tumor cells have fibrillary processes and form gland-like round or elongated structures (rosettes and canals) that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal.

Option C- Medulloblastoma is a WHO grade IV aggressive tumor arising from the cerebellum. The tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes.

Option D- Oligodendroglioma is composed of tumor cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The tumor contains sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin, surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. This gives them fried egg appearance. They contain a network of anastomosing capillaries, resembling chicken wire and also have calcifications.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites may cause deficiency of vitamin B12?
questions.solution:
Diphyllobothrium latum causes deficiency of vitamin B12

The anemia develops because the tapeworm absorbs a large quantity of Vitamin B12 and interferes with its ileal absorption leading to Vitamin B12 deficiency.

In severe cases, patients may exhibit neurologic sequelae of vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man diagnosed with type-2 diabetes mellitus is being treated with metformin for the last 5 years. The deficiency of which of the following vitamins would be most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A vitamin B12 deficiency is most likely in this patient.

Metformin interferes with the calcium-dependent absorption of vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex in the terminal ileum. In addition, it is also proposed to cause alterations in small bowel motility which stimulates bacterial overgrowth and consequential vitamin B12 deficiency, competitive inhibition or inactivation of vitamin B12 absorption, alterations in intrinsic factor (IF) levels and interaction with the cubulin endocytic receptor. As a result, vitamin B12 deficiency can occur.

Decrease in vitamin B12 absorption and levels following metformin use generally begins around the 4th month but clinically observable features of vitamin B12 deficiency manifest by 5–10 years owing to the large body stores in the liver mainly that are not quickly depleted. Additionally, the risk of developing metformin associated vitamin B12 deficiency is greatly influenced by increasing age, metformin dose and duration of use.

Therefore, periodic screening for vitamin B12 deficiency should be considered, especially in patients with peripheral neuropathy or macrocytic anemia. Also, this effect can be reversed with calcium supplementation.

questions.text: A 45 year old iron smelter, presents to the OPD with history of rice water diarrhoea. The image shows the clinical finding that the doctor notes during examination. Which of the following clinical features would be consistent with the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows transverse white lines (Leukonychia striata) called Aldrich Mees Lines typically seen in arsenic poisoning. Tremors are consistent with a diagnosis of arsenic poisoning which should be suspected in a patient of with Aldrich Mees lines, red velvety mucosa, and rice water stools.

Hyperpyrexia, Hyperpigmentation, and Anorexia are associated features.

questions.text: Where can we find the Thornwaldt's cyst?
questions.solution:
Thornwaldt cyst can be found in the midline of the posterior wall of the nasopharynx in the adenoid mass.

  • It is an epithelial-lined median recess found within the adenoid mass and extends from pharyngeal mucosa to the periosteum of the basiocciput.
  • It represents the attachment of notochord to the pharyngeal endoderm during embryonic life.
  • When infected, it may be the cause of persistent postnasal discharge or crusting. Sometimes an abscess can form in the bursa (Thornwaldt’s disease).
  • It is managed surgically by marsupialization of the swelling and complete removal of the lining of the cyst.    

The following is the MRI showing a Thornwald cyst.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.solution:
The site of lesion in a case of internuclear ophthalmoplegia is medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF).

The command for left gaze originates from right cerebral cortex and runs to the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). An output from the left PPRF runs to the left VI nerve nucleus supplying the left lateral rectus, causing abduction. An output from the left PPRF also goes to the right III nerve nucleus via the right MLF causing right eye adduction.

Therefore, a lesion in the right MLF leads to failure of the right eye adduction. The left eye, however, abducts normally. This is called internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: You were posted for screening of deafness in school children under your primary health center. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done for deafness in school children is prescriptive screening. 

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined primarily for their own benefit. It may lead to the early identification of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to decline the disease progression.

Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. Examples of prescriptive screening are:

  • Screening of hemolytic disease in newborns
  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of bacteriuria in pregnancy

Other options:

Option A - Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are screened for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community. Hence, reduces mortality associated with the disease. Examples of prospective screening are:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the citizens
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever

Option B - Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination, to a large population at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population.

Option D - Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most effective screening tests.

Example: Screening for diabetes in the other members of a family for a detected diabetes case since these diseases get aggregated in families.

questions.text: You are planning to conduct a randomized control trial to study the effect of an emollient for eczema, you consider two groups of which one group will receive a placebo. You are considering a blinding trial for this to prevent bias. Which among the following is the most frequent blinding that is used to conduct such trials?
questions.solution:
Although ideally triple blinding should be used, double-blinding is the most frequently used method when blinded-trials are conducted.

Double blinding trials is where neither the group members nor the observers are aware of the group allocation.

Related Pearl: Blinding in Epidemiology

  • Blinding is done in epidemiology to reduce the possibility of bias.
  • Types
    • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.
  • The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the target interventions under National AIDS Control Organisation?

choices.text: Lubricants are given to  homosexual men
Clean needles and syringes are given to injecting drug users
Condoms are not given to bridge population
Opioid substitution therapy is given to Injecting Drug Users

questions.solution:
Bridge populations are supplied with condoms under the NACO target interventions. 

Target interventions: 

General:

  • Detection and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases
  • Condom distribution

For injecting drug users:

  • Distribution of clean needles and syringes.
  • Abscess prevention and management.
  • Opioid substitution therapy.
  • Linkage with detoxification and rehabilitation services.

For homosexual men and transgenders:

  • Provision of lubricants.
  • Provision of project-based clinics for sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of death in patients undergoing blood transfusions?
questions.solution:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is the most common cause of transfusion-related fatalities.

TRALI is due to the presence of anti-HLA class II antibodies in the donor plasma. These antibodies bind recipient leukocytes, which aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. Multiparous women are frequently implicated donors. Recipients with a history of liver disease, smoking, alcohol use are at a higher risk.

It occurs within 6 hours of transfusion and results in hypoxia and signs of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema with bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray. It is managed with supportive care.

questions.text: ABCD2 scoring is used for

choices.text: Risk of stroke following transient ischemic attack
Assessing risk of stroke and for selecting antithrombotic therapy for patients with atrial fibrillation

questions.solution:
ABCD2 Score is used for stroke following transient ischemic attack.

Other options:

  • Pulmonary embolism: Wells clinical prediction rule for pulmonary embolism
  • Assessing risk of stroke and for selecting antithrombotic therapy for patients with atrial fibrillation - CHADS2 score.
  • Cardiovascular disease risk assessment- Many scoring systems are present,one e.g is QRISK score.

Related Pearl: ABCD2 Score

The risk of stroke following TIAs is determined by ABCD2 score.

Clinical factors Score
Age > 60 1
SBP>140 mmHg or DBP >90 mmHg 1
Clinical symptoms
Unilateral weakness 2
Speech disturbances without weakness 1
Duration 
>60min 2
10-59min 1
Diabetes 1
Total Score Sum Each Score
ABCD2 Score Total 3-months Rate of stroke (%)
0 0
1 2
2 3
3 3
4 8
5 12
6 17
7 22

questions.text: The slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
In multiple sclerosis, the slowing of conduction is due to the loss of the myelin sheath.

Under normal circumstances, nerve conduction in myelinated axons occurs in a saltatory manner i.e from one node of Ranvier to another. But, when demyelination sets in, the nerve impulse are unable to travel as fast due to not being saltatory. This produces either a conduction block or delay.

Lesions due to multiple sclerosis begin with perivenular cuffing by inflammatory mononuclear cells. Myelin-specific autoantibodies cause degeneration of myelin sheaths. As lesions evolve, prominent astrocytic proliferation (gliosis) is observed.

Demyelination is the hallmark in the pathology of multiple sclerosis. But, it is not solely a disease affecting the myelin sheath. Partial or total axonal destruction (neuronal loss) can also occur.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents with a history of fever and cough for 2 days. He is living with his wife who recently tested positive for COVID-19 and has been under home isolation. On examination, pulse is 110/min, BP is 78/58 mmHg, the temperature is 101.3 F, RR is 28 and SpO2 is 90%. Which of the following is not recommended in this patient’s management?
questions.solution:
Awake proning should be avoided in patients with hemodynamic instability. 

This patient can be classified to have moderate COVID-19 (SpO2 <94%, RR≥24). The management protocol for moderate COVID includes oxygen support, anticoagulation (LMWH/UFH), corticosteroids and antivirals. Awake proning may be used in moderate COVID in patients who continue to have hypoxia despite oxygen > 4L/min and no contraindications. As this patient is hypotensive and hemodynamically unstable, awake proning is not recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve is least injured during thyroid surgery?
questions.solution:
Marginal mandibular nerve is least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery.

As it is high up (mandibular margin) than the dissection plane of the approach to thyroid surgery.

Other nerves might be at risk of injury if cautiousness is not practiced.

  • Ansa cervicalis may be injured if strap muscles are not cut high enough.
  • The superior laryngeal nerve may be injured near the superior pole of the thyroid.
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve may be injured if dissection is done below cricoid cartilage or near the tracheoesophageal groove.

questions.text: During a splenectomy for a 40-year-old patient with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), the surgeon must ensure the complete removal of all splenic tissue, including accessory spleens, to prevent symptom recurrence. Accessory spleens are commonly found in specific anatomical locations. Where is the most likely site the surgeon should search for an accessory spleen during the operation?
questions.solution:
The splenic hilum and mesentery represent the most common location for accessory spleens. 

An accessory spleen, a supernumerary spleen, a splenule, or a splenunculus refers to splenic tissue found outside the normal spleen. Around 10% to 30% of the population have accessory spleens; with an individual having one to six accessory splenic buds. Furthermore, the size of an accessory spleen can also vary. Most accessory spleens are approximately 1 centimeter but spleens larger than a few centimeters have also been observed.

Accessory spleens are formed due to incomplete fusion of mesenchymal buds during development. 

Most of the accessory spleens are observed in the splenic hilum, the site at which blood vessels enter the spleen; this is followed by the tail of the pancreas, with about 20% of all accessory splenic tissue appearing here. The rest can be found in areas such as the gastrosplenic ligaments, the lienorenal ligaments, the wall of the stomach, the wall of the intestines, the greater omentum, the mesentery, or even the pelvis or scrotum.

Accessory spleens are of importance during procedures like splenectomies and imaging studies.

In a therapeutic splenectomy, it is necessary to remove all accessory splenic tissue for resolution of symptoms failing which symptoms will continue because an accessory spleen is a functional splenic tissue. Conditions that tend to necessitate this sort of management are hemolytic anemia and chronic idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.

Accessory spleens are also relevant when evaluating the results of imaging studies; for example, when a patient undergoes a CT scan, accessory spleens can appear similar to lymph nodes or even a neoplastic growth.

questions.text: All of the following are signs of the base of skull fracture except _____.
questions.solution:
Fox sign is bruising seen over the inguinal ligament in acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

Signs of the skull base fracture:

  • Battle sign: Extravasation of blood results in ecchymosis behind the ear at the mastoid process.
  • Racoon eye: Periorbital ecchymoses (black eye)
  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea
  • CSF otorrhea
  • Anosmia
  • Cranial nerve palsy: damage to the facial or vestibulocochlear nerve, resulting in vertigo, ipsilateral deafness, or facial paralysis
  • Hemotympanum

Battle sign:

Racoon eyes:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with an injured femoral artery following a stab injury to the right thigh. Which of the following suture material would be ideal for the repair of the artery?
questions.solution:
Polypropylene is the ideal suture material to repair the femoral artery.

The vascular anastomosis requires an accurate and watertight closure. Hence it requires a non-absorbable material that can provide tensile strength for a longer period. In addition, the material should be non-braided to avoid platelet adherence to the suture material. Hence, polypropylene which is a non-absorbable monofilament is used for vascular anastomoses.

Related Pearl: Suture materials

Suture Types Uses

Absorbable suture materials
Catgut Plain/Chromic

Ligate superficial vessels

Suture subcutaneous tissues, stomas and other tissues that heal rapidly
Polyglactin (Vicryl) Braided multifilament

Gut and biliary anastomoses

Vascular ligatures

Kidney and ureter surgeries.

Subcuticular wound

Polydioxanone

Monofilament

Dyed or undyed

Used in tissues where slightly longer wound support is required

Poliglecaprone (Monocryl)

 Monofilament

Subcuticular suturing of skin

Soft tissue ligation

Gastrointestinal and muscle surgery
Non-absorbable suture materials
Silk

Braided or twisted multifilament

Coated (with wax or silicon) or uncoated

Ligation and suturing when long-term tissue support is necessary

e.g., for securing drains externally, two-layer bowel anastomoses

Surgical steel

Monofilament or multifilament

Closure of sternotomy wounds
Nylon

Monofilament or braided multifilament

Skin closure

Abdominal wall closure

Hernia repair

Neurosurgery

Polybutester

Monofilament

Exhibits elasticity. Favoured for use in plastic surgery
 

Polypropylene (Prolene)

 Monofilament   

Cardiovascular surgery and vascular anastomosis 

Plastic surgery

General surgical subcuticular skin closure

questions.text: The following instrument is used to augment labour in a 28-year-old primigravida via low rupture of membranes. Identify this instrument.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is Kocher's artery forceps and is identified by the presence of a single tooth at the tip.

Kocher's artery forceps are used to achieve hemostasis by holding bleeding vessels. They are also used in low rupture of membranes to augment labour or for the surgical induction of labour. 

The difference between artery forceps and needle holders is in the edge and smoothness of corrugations. Artery forceps have smooth edges and single lined corrugations whereas, needle holders have rough edges and crossed lines forming square to diamond shaped corrugations.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is being evaluated for bleeding per vagina. She attained menopause at the age of 47. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Ovarian Follicular cysts are least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding. They are usually asymptomatic unless they rupture, hemorrhage or the ovary undergoes torsion which would manifest as an acute abdomen. They occur when there is the failure of absorption of fluid in an incompletely developed follicle or anovulation. 

Postmenopausal bleeding is diagnosed when there is bleeding per vagina after 6 months of amenorrhoea after the age of 40 (menopausal age). 

Causes of postmenopausal bleeding include: 

  • Genital tract trauma (Option A)
  • Cervical erosion, inflammation, polyp, or ulcer
  • Uterus - endometritis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma (Option C), polyp, or sarcoma
  • Fallopian tube malignancy
  • Ovarian tumors such as Brenner tumor, granulosa cell tumor (Option D)
  • Hypertension and blood dyscrasia
  • Urinary tract trauma, bladder carcinoma
  • Hemorrhoid, anal fissures, and rectal cancers confused as bleeding per vagina
  • Use of estrogens as hormone replacement therapy, tamoxifen.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: Cervical incompetence or cervical insufficiency is characterized by _______

choices.text: Repeated mid trimester painful cervical dilatation
Repeated mid trimester painless cervical dilatation
Repeated third trimester painful cervical dilatation
Repeated third trimester painless cervical dilatation

questions.solution:
Cervical incompetence is characterized by repeated mid trimester painless cervical dilatation and escape of liquor amnii followed by painless expulsion of products of conception. The usual timings are 16 to 24 weeks.

Etiology and risk factors:

  • Prior cervical destructive surgery
  • In utero DES exposure
  • Prior induced or spontaneous first and second trimester abortions
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Multiple gestations

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with persistent diurnal incontinence and abdominal distention is being evaluated for a posterior urethral valve. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is the investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve.

Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are obstructing membranous folds within the lumen of the posterior urethra, which hinders the outflow of urine from the urinary bladder and may precipitate chronic renal disease in children.

It occurs due to disruption of normal embryonic development of the male urethra between the 9th and 14th weeks of intrauterine life, resulting in the formation of membranous folds within the lumen of the posterior urethra.

Children with PUV who are not diagnosed before birth may present with delayed voiding or a poor urinary stream. Infants are predisposed to repeated urinary tract infections (UTIs). Other common signs and symptoms may include a palpable abdominal mass, failure to thrive, lethargy, poor feeding, urosepsis, and urinary ascites. Older boys may have persistent diurnal incontinence or abdominal distention. Physical examination in the newborn typically discloses a palpable walnut-sized bladder, which corresponds to the hypertrophic detrusor muscle.

Other options:

Option A: Trans-rectal ultrasound scan (TRUS) is usually performed in conjunction with a biopsy of the prostate in male patients with an abnormal digital rectal examination of the prostate

Option B: Renal nuclear scintigraphy with a technetium-99m-labelled dimercaptosuccinic acid can be used to visualise any abnormality or thinning of the renal parenchyma, like renal scarring

Option D: A non-contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice in a patient with suspected urinary tract calculi

questions.text: Identify the following deformity associated with spinal TB.
questions.solution:
The skeletal deformity shown above is gibbus. It involves the collapse of two or three vertebral levels and presents as sharp posterior angulation.

Spinal tuberculosis may present with the following skeletal deformities:

  • The collapse of a single vertebra causing prominence of a single spinous process is known as knuckle.
  • The collapse of two or three vertebral levels presenting as sharp posterior angulation is known as gibbus/kyphos.
  • The collapse of anterior vertebral bodies involving multiple vertebrae leads to exaggerated curvature of the vertebral column known as kyphosis.
  • The collapse of the entire vertebral body (not just the anterior part of the vertebra) leads to concertina collapse/vertebra plana. It is usually seen in tuberculosis of the central vertebral body.

questions.text:
In aiding the diagnosis of a patient with suspected pneumoperitoneum, what is the most sensitive imaging modality among the given options:

A. Erect chest x-ray PA view

B. Supine abdomen x-ray AP view

C. Abdomen x-ray with left lateral decubitus view 

D. Erect abdomen x-ray PA view 

E. Contrast-enhanced CT
questions.solution:
Contrast-enhanced CT is the most sensitive imaging modality used in the diagnosis of minimal or suspected pneumoperitoneum. Free air as less as 1 ml can be detected. Small pockets of air trapped in peritoneal recesses can also be detected. 

An erect chest x-ray is the next most sensitive investigation, and also the initial investigation carried out to diagnose pneumoperitoneum. Free air under the diaphragm, also known as the crescent sign is seen here and it can detect around 3-4 ml of free air in the abdomen. 

If the patient is unable to stand, then an abdomen x-ray with left lateral decubitus view is more sensitive than supine or erect abdominal films to detect pneumoperitoneum.

questions.text: A 24-yr-old man presents with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse. What is this called?
questions.solution:
An excess desire for sexual intercourse in males is called satyriasis. 

Satyriasis is also known as Don Juanism. In some men, sexual activity is a means to mask their deep feelings of inferiority. Some have unconscious homosexual impulses, which they deny by compulsive sexual contact with women. Many of them are no longer interested in the women after sex.

Other options

  • Nymphomania: An excess desire for sexual intercourse in females
  • Frotteurism: Sexual gratification achieved by touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting person.
  • Masochism: The tendency to derive sexual gratification from one's own pain or humiliation.

Note: Don Juanism represents hypersexuality in males.

questions.text: A 57 year old male patient who has been diagnosed with aggressive pancreatic cancer presents with intractable abdominal pain unresponsive to opioids. The anesthetist decides to opt for a regional block. Which of the following would he choose?
questions.solution:
The block he would choose in the case of pancreatic cancer is celiac plexus block.

The celiac plexus block is indicated in patients with pain arising from the abdominal viscera, specifically intraabdominal cancers. 

The celiac ganglia are generally clustered at the level of the body of the L1 vertebra, posterior to the inferior vena cava on the right and lateral to the aorta on the left. It is posterior to the pancreas. 

The patient is placed in a prone position and 15-20 ml of local anesthetic is injected under fluoroscopic, CT, or ultrasound guidance. The needed should be inserted 7-8cm from the midline at the inferior edge of the spinous process of L1. 

The approaches that can be taken for this block include the posterior retrocrural approach, posterior anterocrural approach, posterior transaortic approach, an anterior approach. 

The most common complication is postural hypotension. This occurs due to blocking of visceral sympathetic innervation which results in vasodilation. To prevent this, the patient should be adequately hydrated intravenously. 

Other options: 

Option A: The stellate block is indicated in patients with head, neck, arm, and upper chest pain. 

Option B: The lumbar sympathetic block is indicated in painful conditions involving the pelvis and lower extremities like a peripheral vascular disease. 

Option D: The superior hypogastric plexus block is indicated in pelvic pain that is unresponsive to lumbar or caudal epidural blocks. It is used in patients with cancer of the pelvic organs or non-cancer pelvic pain.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding Scleredema.

choices.text: Erythema and a peau d’orange appearance of the skin
Can occur in association with Diabetes
Associated with sclerodactyly or Raynauds Phenomenon

questions.solution:
Scleroderma is associated with sclerodactyly or Raynauds Phenomenon (and not scleredema).

The dermis is 3–4 times thicker than normal. The subcutaneous tissue is also involved with fat being replaced by coarse collagen fibers.

Scleredema : 

  • Scleredema is symmetrical diffuse progressive non‐pitting swelling and induration of the upper part of the body caused by a thickened dermis and deposition of mucin.
  • Erythema and a peau d’orange appearance of the skin are commonly observed. The hands and feet are characteristically spared.
  • Diabetic scleredema is the most common type.

Image: Scleredema in a diabetic patient with firm non‐pitting edema and induration on the upper back, neck, and shoulders on an erythematous background.

Note: Scleredema and scleroderma are different entities. In contrast to systemic sclerosis, scleredema is not associated with sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, nail fold capillary changes or serum autoantibodies.

questions.text: Laser most commonly used in laryngeal surgeries_____
questions.solution:
• Endoscopic resection with the CO2 laser. Carcinoma of the mobile membranous vocal cord is traditionally treated with radiotherapy.
  • Such lesions can be precisely excised with the CO2 laser under the microscope with the same good results.
  • Laser excision has the advantages of lower cost, lower duration of treatment and morbidity.
